natural_text: You may lose consciousness at the time of the head injury but this does not always happen . Classically , someone who develops an intracranial extradural haematoma loses consciousness at the time of the head injury and then has a ' lucid interval ' of a few hours after the head injury where they appear relatively well and normal . Later , they deteriorate and lose consciousness again as the haematoma forms . However , not everyone shows this classic pattern . If you do not lose consciousness after the initial head injury , or if you regain consciousness , you may experience drowsiness or a severe headache . You may also feel sick ( have nausea ) and/or be sick ( have vomiting ) . You may become confused and may develop weakness of an arm and/or a leg on one side of your body and/or speech difficulties . Sometimes a fit ( seizure ) can occur . Some people with an intracranial extradural haematoma can be talking one minute and appear relatively well and can then become very ill and lose consciousness the next . If you have a significant head injury , you should be taken to hospital urgently by ambulance . Anyone who loses consciousness at the time of a head injury should be taken to hospital straightaway . Anyone who develops any of the other symptoms mentioned above after a head injury should also see a doctor urgently .,

The nerves and nervous system are affected in about 1 in 20 people with sarcoidosis . The heart is affected in about 1 in 50 people with sarcoidosis . The time of onset of symptoms to diagnosis ranged from three to four weeks in one-third of reported cases. About 70% had no symptoms at the time of diagnosis, with detection mostly by chest X-ray. Approximately 40% had spontaneous resolution with minimal or no residual clinical or radiographic changes, but the remaining half continued to show intermittent symptoms and signs or progression to irreversible form. A variety of clinical studies have been reported. The overall five-year survival is about 40%. Death is most likely to occur during the first year, usually secondary to respiratory failure. Persistent and recurrent disease is more common among patients with an acute on-set of illness and multisystem disease  especially in black patients who are at particular risk for poor outcomes. Sarcoidosis has a tendency to recur, and this is more common in blacks and women. Sarcotubers and cardiac sarcoid are associated with a poor prognosis. natural_text: As many as 2 in 3 people with sarcoidosis do not need any specific treatment . Their sarcoidosis will get better of its own accord over the following two to five years . In about 1 in 3 people with sarcoidosis , it becomes persistent ( chronic ) and may require treatment . Someone with sarcoidosis can ( rarely ) be severely affected and may die . This is usually due to severe involvement of the lungs , leading to respiratory failure . The outlook tends to be not so good if sarcoidosis affects areas of your body outside your lungs , particularly if it affects your heart or your nerves . People who develop sarcoidosis quickly , over a few weeks , tend to have a better outlook . So do those who develop erythema nodosum , or those who just have swollen lymph glands seen on their chest X - ray and no real breathing or chest symptoms . Yes, by treating modifiable risk factors, including management of comorbidities and medication profile ( see below for more details ). However, the evidence is scarce. So far, studies on non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs ( NSAIDs ), hyperuricemia, hypomagnesemia and hyperparathyroidism have been inconsistent about preventing CPPD [3–5]. prompt: How are autistic spectrum disorders ( ASDs ) diagnosed ?
watermarked_text: How are autistic spectrum disorders ( ASDs ) diagnosed ? A definitive diagnosis of ASD can only be made if a person is over eighteen months of age and is able to speak. Between eighteen months and two years, a diagnosis is possible if large language deficits are present together with a lack of interest in other children, repetitive behavior, limited eye contact, and unusual body movements and gestures. After the age of two years, ASD can be diagnosed exclusively in the presence of language deficit and other behavioral symptoms such as impairments of joint attention, shared use of gestures, pretend play, or the use of symbols. The Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, fourth edition, text revision (DSM-IV-TR) lists several different diagnoses within the ASD category  . In general, the term "autism" is reserved for children who have both language delays and profound impairments in social and communicative skills that are accompanied by repetitive behaviors.

watermarked_text: Can my body get used to my nitrate medication ? Yes, your body can adapt to your medication, causing a decrease in the effectiveness, a process known as tolerance. In this case you may need higher doses to maintain the efficacy. However, this condition is more common with antianginal drugs than with nitrates. prompt: What is a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA ) ?
watermarked_text: What is a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA ) ? A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary (<24 hours) blockage of blood flow to the brain, usually from blockages in the neck arteries that may be diagnosed with brain imaging tests of the neck artery structures such as a duplex ultrasound, arterial CT scan, arteriography and carotid Magnetic Resonance Angiography. The lack of brain blood flow causes a temporary reduction in the ability to perform certain tasks and functions which stop, alter or distort the individual's perception of things for a short span of time. The individual may suddenly lose some of his/her movement abilities, vision, hearing and speech activity or even lose consciousness and/or emotional abilities depending on the level of brain blood flowing due to the blockage ( 39 ). The clinical symptoms usually are resolved within 24 hours but in approximately 33% of persons presenting with TIA, a new stroke
unwatermarked_text: What is a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA ) ?A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a temporary condition in which, because of reduced blood flow, a part of the brain is temporarily deprived of blood and oxygen, causing symptoms similar to those of a stroke. These symptoms last no more than 24 h. TIAs are often mild compared to stroke symptoms; in fact, about one-third of silent strokes are actually TIAs. If the brain is only briefly and mildly affected, most people with TIA will show few symptoms. TIA is a significant event, however, because those with a history of TIA have a fourto- 10-fold risk of ischemic stroke. Stroke risk rises to 40.6% in men and 16.1% in women within a year after a TIA  ( http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26532319).
natural_text: A TIA causes symptoms similar to a stroke but the symptoms last for less than 24 hours . It is due to a temporary lack of blood to a part of the brain . In most cases , a TIA is caused by a tiny blood clot that becomes stuck in a small blood vessel ( artery ) in the brain . This blocks the blood flow and a part of the brain is starved of oxygen . The affected part of the brain is without oxygen for just a few minutes and soon recovers . This is because the blood clot either breaks up quickly or nearby blood vessels are able to compensate . Unlike a stroke , the symptoms of a TIA soon go . However , you should see a doctor urgently if you have a TIA , as you are at increased risk of having a full stroke . See separate leaflet called Transient Ischaemic Attack for more details .,

unwatermarked_text: Are all travellers at risk for Traveller 's Diarrhoea ? All travellers are not necessarily at risk for TD since there are numerous destinations where it is not endemic (i.e., Alaska, Iceland, Greenland, Sweden, Finland, etc.). However, recent history of travel to high risk areas (endemic with traveler's diarrhea) are at higher risk of getting TD. In addition, travelers' previous history of diarrheal episodes seems to be an important risk factor for the development of traveler' diarrheagenic disease. The type of food taken by different travelers differ from person to person, thus risk to get TD might also vary. For example, vegetarians are more at risk getting travel diarrheogenic disease, than non-vegetarians, if they travel to India. This is probably due to the low intake of parasite killing (fresh fruit, vegetables) food stuffs in vegetables.

There is a different risk depending on where you travel to : High - risk areas : South and Southeast Asia , Central America , West and North Africa , South America , East Africa . Medium - risk areas : Russia , China , Caribbean , South Africa . Low - risk areas : North America , Western Europe , Australia and New Zealand . Sometimes outbreaks of diarrhoea can occur in travellers staying in one hotel or , for example , those staying on a cruise ship . People travelling in more remote areas ( for example , trekkers and campers ) may also have limited access to medical care if they do become unwell . People ' backpacking ' are more likely to become unwell than people on business trips staying in hotels .,

Insertion of LARCs depends on accessibility to trained personnel, cost of the implants or devices and availability of contraceptives. An injection of a progestogen hormone is given every three months ( two months for one brand ) , most commonly into the muscle in your bottom . Read about the contraceptive injection . watermarked_text: What are the treatments for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ? CO­PV, being a disease caused by external agents (tobacco smoking and exposure to other risk factors), can be prevented. After the development of respiratory symptoms, treatment is focused predominantly on slowing disease progression. The initial approach is focused on smoking habit cessation. A multidisciplinary approach is essential. This includes early treatment with bronchodilators (β-agonists and anticholinergics), inhaled corticosteroids with or without long-acting β-agonist for COPD which is more severe, prevention of exacerbations, oxygen therapy for hypoxemia, and pulmonary rehabilitation (79). unwatermarked_text: What are the treatments for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease ? The most important thing for treatment is to make every effort to prevent the first attack. Smoking cessation is essential . Secondary treatments must then be based on the severity of the disease  and include : the use of oxygen therapy with a pulse oximeter that can monitor the oxygen saturation ; and the use of nebulized bronchodilators . Nebulized bronchodilation, alone, is not enough . It must be combined with physical therapy to improve breathing and maintain muscle strength . Physiotherapy is aimed at : breathing exercises: diaphragmatic breathing; posture correction. Proper positioning of the body reduces the work of breathing and improves lung ventilation ; relaxation exercises; aerobic exercises. Moderate to high intensity aerobic exercise is recommended (e.g.; walking, cycling, swimming, and stationary cycling), with an inpatient program preferred in cases of disease severity ; respiratory rehabilitation;

You lie flat for a few minutes and your heart rate and blood pressure are recorded . After standing up , further recordings of your heart rate and blood pressure are taken over the following 10 minutes . Tilt table test . You lie flat on a special bed and your heart rate and blood pressure are recorded . The bed is then tilted ( head end up ) for up to 45 minutes while further recordings of your heart rate and blood pressure are taken . watermarked_text: What are other treatments and therapies for Cerebral Palsy ? There is no specific, proven therapy that has been shown to reverse the functional impairments associated with CP. Treatments are directed at improving functioning, preventing deformities and reducing associated complications. Early physical therapy and passive range of motion exercises are important to minimize spasticity, deformities, pain, and associated contractures, as well as to improve positioning and control of the extremities. In severe cases, the use of orthopedic braces, denervation surgical techniques, or intramuscular injections of Botulin are helpful in relieving spasticity and deformity. If a spastic limb is not ambulating, a orthosist should be fitted to help prevent deformity, but care should be taken as some patients with fixed deformities cannot tolerate bracing and should be checked regularly during the course of treatment. Surgery may be necessary in cases of fixed deformity or progressive bone erosions secondary to joints

Complications can include : Disseminated intravascular coagulation - this means the formation of blood clots in the small blood vessels throughout the body . Failure of the adrenal glands ( the glands that sit on top of the kidneys that produce adrenaline , steroids and other important body chemicals ) . Multiorgan failure - this means that several organs of the body stop working properly . These can include the heart , lungs and kidneys . As with any severe illness which needs intensive treatment in hospital , people recovering from sepsis may experience physical and psychological difficulties and these difficulties may last for several years . Physical problems may include feeling very tired , muscle weakness , feeling short of breath , chest pains , fluid swelling ( oedema ) , joint pains , poor appetite , disturbed vision , skin numbness or pins and needles , and frequent illness caused by further infections . Psychological difficulties may include feeling anxious , feeling low or depressed , nightmares , poor sleep , poor concentration and problems with memory .,

natural_text: When an ear is noted to be prominent within the first few weeks of life , it is possible to reshape it by applying a small splint to the rim . The cartilage or gristle of a new - born 's ear is very floppy and easily remoulded and after several weeks of splintage a permanent correction can be achieved . The older the child , the more stiff the cartilage and the longer the period of splintage must be . By the age of six months the cartilage is too hard to be remoulded and a surgical solution is required . Pinnaplasty or otoplasty is an operation which adjusts the shape of the cartilage within the ear to create the missing folds and to allow the ear to lie closer to the side of the head . Because the operation is carried out from behind the ears , a small scar is left close to the groove between the ear and the side of the head . The procedure can be carried out under local anaesthetic , but in young children a general anaesthetic is usually required . Where the lobe of the ear is especially large , a small procedure to reduce its size may also be required .,

natural_text: Endobronchial ultrasound - guided transbronchial needle aspiration is a special technique used to take samples of body tissue from inside the chest . It is also known as EBUS TBNA for short . The procedure is carried out using a special kind of bronchoscope . This is a thin flexible kind of ' telescope ' which passes through the mouth and into the airways . The bronchoscope ( often shortened to ' scope ' ) allows doctors to see inside the lungs and carry out the procedure . Endobronchial means from inside or within the bronchus . The bronchi ( the plural of bronchus ) are large tube - like airways . They take air from the windpipe ( trachea ) to the smaller airways , called the bronchioles . During the procedure ultrasound is used to help the doctor doing the test see the structures just outside the airways . This gives the test the first part of its name . The scope also contains a very fine needle . This needle is used to take samples of body tissue by pushing through the bronchus to the tissue on the other side . The needle holds the sample of tissue ; this is called aspiration . Transbronchial means across the bronchus , giving the name transbronchial needle aspiration .,

Most patients will not respond to simple dietary therapy alone, but will require immunosuppression to improve their condition. Persistent nonspecific symptoms may be associated with long-term treatment with corticosteroids. Patients with longstanding glomerulopathies often have progressive irreversible kidney damage. Over time, the filtering units of the kidney, called glomeruli, may be significantly damaged or lost to proteinuria ( excess protein in the urine ). natural_text: In many cases , glomerulonephritis can be a temporary problem that can completely get better ( resolve ) . However , in other cases , glomerulonephritis can become gradually worse over time , cause permanent damage to the glomeruli and lead to chronic kidney disease . In some cases , this can progress to end - stage kidney disease . A kidney biopsy can help your doctors to predict the likely outcome in your individual case .
